Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 11:09AM - edited Jul 5, 2008 11:11AM by Curlylocks Hi Water,  I had an ooperectomy on May 26, am 44 was 41 when diagnosed with er/pr+ IDC, grade 3 and 3 positive lymph nodes.  I was pre-meno when diagnosed, had Zoladex injections for 1 1/2 years along with Armidex.  My oncologist brought up the oopherectomy six months almost a year after I first mentioned it.  I am happy that I no longer need the Zoladex injections (one less drug in my body) and for me the transition to surgical menopause has not been difficult as a result.   Yes I do have insonmia, hotflashes (although they seem to have gotten better 6 weeks out of the surgery) but dont have the swinging mood swings that I had on Zoladex and it has been easier to loose some weight since being off it too! I had a  9 working days off after surgery, was tired the first couple days back but the stamina slowly built up after about 3 weeks. My memory has gotten pretty poor since being shot into chemical menopause and now surgically, it gets very frustrating some days.  Like now I just realized that I have my laundry in the washer since last night....duh...gotta love those light bulb moments.LOL.  I do not regret my decision to eliminate those little "estrogen demons"....

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 04:39PM - edited Jun 16, 2008 04:39PM by Curlylocks Cupcake, I am 44 and am almost a 3 year survivor of Invasive Cancer that invaded outside the breast into 3 of my lymph nodes, also a Grade III which means it was aggressive and my tumour was 4 cm.  I was staged at IIb. Breast cancer is not the death sentence and many, many women are living long healthy lives after treatment. I know the feeling all too well of being "hit by the 2 x 4" and hearing those words you have cancer.  I remember it like it was yesterday....but today I am happy, healthy and cancer free. You will have an indication of the stage that you are once you have surgery and get your pathology report back, yes the waiting totally sucks and seems to take forever.  Its the hurry up and wait rollercoaster that you are about to embark on.... I had a lumpectomy with clear margins, 6 months of chemo, 5 1/2 weeks of radiation, recently an oopherectomy to remove my "little estrogen demons" and have been on hormonal drugs for 2 years.  Yes, this diagnosis is very tough emotionally but once you get a treatment plan into place things will feel a little more "less out of your control"..... Time does heal the emotional wounds and yes there is definitely tons of HOPE and lots of living left to do for you....keep your head held high and put on those boxing gloves to beat the crap out of this beast! The breast cancer terminology takes a little getting use to: bc = breast cancer idc = invasive ductual carcinoma snb = sential node biopsy dcis = ductual carcinoma institu  er/pr status = whether cancer was fueled by estrogen ---  + = yes, - = no Staging - indicated by Stage 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4. Your doctor should be able to tell you what type of cancer you have by the biopsy results.  Staging is not determined until after you have surgery and your lymph nodes are tested to see how many nodes may be affected, as well as a hormone receptor test (er/pr status) and her2 status, all of which  will help your medical team put a treatment plan into place.   Baseline scans are usually done when cancer has invaded outside of the breast.  I had a liver/abdomen scan, bone scan and chest xray and all turned out negative for spread.  Your doctor may wanting to get down to the business of getting rid of any active cancer cells prior to surgery.  Come back here often if you have any questions, alot of us have been in your shoes... Michele

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2007 04:46PM Curlylocks wrote: I am a 2 year survivor and have been where you are now and it is tough.  Sorry you are having so much pain.  I had 23 lymph nodes removed and I can tell you that the area where the nodes was removed was much more painful than the actual incision from my lumpectomy.  The pain did stay with me quite awhile...more than 3 weeks.  I found sleeping with a pillow underneath my arm helped.  I had to do this for a few months post surgery.  It is important to continue to do the stretching exercises as it will help in the healing process and your arm will continue to get better slowly.  Dont overdo it, I know that you want to feel "normal" yesterday but you have been through alot and it does take time and patience for things to heal. With starting chemo, you will need some extra help especially with the children and everyday household chores - making meals, etc.  My first 4-5 days of every treatment were the most challenging... All the best in your journey. Michele

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 03:25AM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Fly, ER+ cancer is good in that you have the hormonals to continue with as treatment.   It is a pill that you take everyday for 5 years.  For pre-menopausal women the choice would be Tamoxifen.  For post-menopausal women some use Tamoxifen while others are given a newer drug called an Arimitose Inhibitor (AI for short).  There are 3 AI's on the market now, Armasoin, Femera and Armidex.  You may also take the AI's if you are surgically put into menopause (ovary removal) or chemically by having an injection of either Zoladex or Lupron on a monthly or every 3 month basis. I was diagnosed at age 41 with a highly positive er cancer, had 3 positive lymph nodes and a 4 cm tumour.  My oncologist wanted to be on the aggressive side of treatment for me due to the age.  I am on Armidex and Zoladex injections.  I will be getting my ovaries removed on May 26 so that I can remain on Armidex and stop the Zoladex injections. Studies are showing that AI's are a little more cutting edge as far as preventing reoccurance but are not without their side effects as most drugs  are.  An HER+ cancer would mean that the cancer is more aggressive but the good news is that there is a drug called Herceptin which is given over the course of a year via IV.  It is the new wonder drug and saving many lives!! All the best with your treatments. Sorry that this new language of breast cancer is so confusing.  You too will be an expert soon.... Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 01:38AM - edited Jun 8, 2013 01:40AM by Curlylocks I so this post and wanted to respond as it is appropriate to my family.  I was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 41 (I just turned 49), my aunt had stage 0 diagnosed at age 60.  My youngest sister was diagnosed at age 42 in 2010 and passed away last year at age 44.  My older sister who is 50 may now have bc as well.  She went for her regular mamogram/ultra sound in January, got called back for more testing...her doctor recommended she have an MRI due to high risk first degree family history.  She went back for more testing and they said she had a few cysts.  In the meantime, she had to go to genetic counselling to get into the "High Risk" screening program which would get her the MRI.  She had the MRI on May 22 and got called back for further investigation.  Final tests incuding ultrasound confirmed she has a 1cm lump in her right breast and is awaiting a biopsy on June 17. My youngest sister who died was tested for the BRCA1 and 2 gene a few months before she died and it came back negative.  I have never been tested but will be going within the next year so that I can get into the High Risk screening program.  With two sisters and a possible third (first degree relatives) having bc there has to be a genetic link somewhere.  As other posters have said their are genes that may be genetic that have not been identified as of yet.  Nothing else makes sense. When you said you went for your Yearly Exams, was that a mamogram or Physical?  If you havent had a mamogram, I would ask your doctor to do one to find out what the lumps are.   Having hair growing around your breast does not sound like a symptom of breast cancer.   Its hard to say without having testing done if it is bc because everyone presents differently.  Some women have no visible lumps, some lumps are benign conditions, some women have pain others dont. Here in Canada they have criteria for doing genetic testing - you have to be diagnosed with bc and have three first degree family members.  Ie. sisters, mother.  I am not sure about aunts and cousins and the age that they are diagnosed is also taken into account.  In my case my aunt was not considered familly history as she was diagnosed in her 60's. All the best to you in finding out what the lumps are. Michele
Posts.Title: 4 deceased and 4 surviving breast cancer victims in my family ashslillian9 Curlylocks

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 06:37PM - edited Dec 21, 2007 06:37PM by Curlylocks Hi Angie, I am sorry that you got the "news" that you have invasive cancer. I was diagnosed in Oct 05 at age 41 with invasive cancer, a 4 cm tumour and 3 positive lymph nodes out of the 23 removed.  I have to say that the beginning part of this journey is the hardest as you really dont know what you are dealing with until you do have surgery and the final pathlogy report is done.  The waiting and wondering is extremely hard and so unfair to all of us fighting this disease.... More than likely you dont have to worry that the cancer will spread before you have surgery.  Most cancers have been in our bodies for 6-8 years prior to discovery so a few weeks is not unreasonable to wait.  I had my surgery 3 weeks after diagnosis. Once you see the surgeon and have a treatment plan in place, you will feel like you have more control of this disease. Breast cancer is not a death sentence.  I am proof that you can come out the other side of this nasty disease and once again be a healthy person.  I seriously could not plan a day ahead into my future when first diagnosed but life has once again become happy and I am living a "new normal" beyond breast cancer. Come here often to ask any questions, voice your fears or just to vent as we understand having travelled the same journey that you are about to embark on. Big hugs to you tonight and the very best to you and your family during this holiday season. Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2012 07:12AM Curlylocks wrote: Ni neugirl I only wish that there was a cure for breast cancer.  I am 7 years out of diagnosis with stage IIb, 4cm tumour with 3 positive lymph nodes.  This diagnosis is sure to throw you into a tailspin and wondering what the future might hold.  I agree with Mary Anne about HOPE, she is actually a dear friend that I have met through these boards.  If you dont have hope, it makes it difficult to see the good in the world and think about the future. Dont beat yourself up and give yourself time to mourn the loss of your old self.  The first year I couldnt even think about years ahead because the truth is I thought I wouldnt be alive in six months.   A new self will emerge with time.  You will get through this, for me the first few years are the hardest emotionally to deal with.  It takes time to find your "new normal" but it will happen!
Posts.Title: Diagnosis very hard to handle neugirl Appetite4life

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 06:20AM - edited Mar 16, 2008 06:21AM by Curlylocks Lloyd, I too found my tumour on my own after having had a clear mamo the previous year.   With younger women it is hard to find cancer, as my doctor's said it is like looking for a needle in a haystack.   I was diagnosed at age 41 with no family history of bc.  This is a tough question to answer as most lumps that are found by women themselves have been there for at least 6-8 years.  Is that early detection, I'm not sure??? In the breast cancer world early stage cancer is stage 0 (dcis), stage 1 and 2.  Stage 2 has 2 levels 2a and 2b, this depends on the size of the tumour and if any lymph nodes are involved. Early stage cancer to me ideally would be dcis.  However, I was diagnosed stage 2b as I had a 4 cm tumour and 3 positive lymph nodes.  The good news is I continue to be cancer free and this is my 3rd year of survivorship. I'm sorry that you are having to deal with this blasted disease.  The shock will wear off and then you will get angry and your wife will start fighting this disease.  This is a long tough emotional journey for both you and your wife.  I bought a book for my husband at the begining called "The Breast Cancer Husband" by Marc Silver, it truely was a godsend and helped him to understand the emotions and treatment aspect of this disease. My best advice is to just be there for her, especially emotionally as the not knowing, wondering what is in store for her treatment wise and just being plan scared of this whole diagnosis do take a huge toll on you.  Make sure that you take care of yourself too....dont be afraid to ask for counselling if needed as you will be no good to her if you are a basketcase too!  My husband was so angry at first he punched a hole in the wall, not a very smart thing to do.... Now 2 1/2 years later life is a "new normal" and I am happy, healthy and we are much closer as a couple than prior to bc. Come back here often to ask any questions that you may have and if your wife feels up to it ask her to come here too.  This board saved my sanity when I was first diagnosed! Michele

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 10:00AM Curlylocks wrote: Pryclla, I'm so sorry that you and your family are having to deal with this blasted disease called breast cancer. I would like to chime in with others in that the 6 month time frame may be if she does nothing about treatment. I was 41 when I was diagnosed 2 1/2 years ago, my tumour was invasive, 4 cm and I had 3 positive lymph nodes.  I had the kitchen sink thrown at me as far as treatment goes --- lumpectomy with the removal of 23 lymph nodes, 6 months of chemo, 5 1/2 weeks of radiation and now on hormonals.  I am know currently in remission and doing well. Please try and talk to your mom and let her know that treatments today are totally doable and the meds that they have for chemo REALLY DO WORK!!  It is not something that I want to have to repeat over but would definitely do it again, if I needed to... Your mom has lots to live for including you, she may need to talk to a counsellor to help her sort out her feelings of anger and get onto getting treatment and getting back to healthy living again.  Please tell her it is not time to give up but that it is certainly okay and NORMAL to be angry, cry when she needs to because yes this does SUCK and no one deserves to have to deal with this disease... Tell her that you love her and want to see her get well and encourage her to seek the help see needs to deal with this! All the best in helping out your mom, you are a great and caring daughter. Michele

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2013 05:00PM - edited Jun 10, 2013 05:03PM by Curlylocks My Dad passed away last year too on June 24/13, god bless him.  He had cancer twice, third time it was pancreatic that spread to his liver. He was gone in 2.5 months after being diagnosed.  It makes sense when you say he could be the gene carrier. My sister who passed away was 44, she had genetic testing done about four months before she died.  Her test was negative.  Here in Canada, the guidelines are a little different than in the U.S.  They wouldnt do genetic testing on my older sister as she hadnt had breast cancer, but did genetic counselling so she could get into the High Risk Screening Program to get an MRI. I have never been tested, had an appt but cancelled it...this was before my younger sister was rediagnosed a 2nd time in March last year. At the time (it was about 2 years ago)  I didnt see any benefit in getting it done as I had my ovaries removed at age 44.  I will reschedule now for the testing so that I too can get into the High Risk Screening Program, they wont do an MRI on me unless I do...pretty stupid considering I am a bc survivor. My other sister who is ten months younger than me lives in a different part of Canada, she is eligible to go for MRI`s every year and has been for several years.  She has never been tested, again as she is not a bc survivor she wont be eligible.  Another criteria, is you have to have three living first degree family members with bc and sadly the fact that my youngest sister is no longer living they dont count here into the equation. Michele

Posts.Content: Curlylocks wrote: I would like to introduce myself.  I am not new to these boards, myself am a 7.5 year bc survivor - diagnosed with bc at age 41.  I lost my sister last April to breast cancer.  Now my older sister (50) is going for biopsies next Tuesday. A little history on what is going on with my older sister....she had her regular Annual Mamogram in January this year, got a call back more testing and they determined she had cysts.  Fast forward to May 22/13 she had an MRI due to high first degree risk of bc and dense breasts.  She got a call back to go for more testing, compressed mamo and ultrasound last Thursday.  The ultrasound confirmed a 1cm lump in her right breast that needs to be biopsed.   She was originally scheduled to have that biopsy next Monday, however, got another call from the hospital saying they were cancelling that biopsy and rescheduling it for next Tuesday as they have reviewed her MRI and now want to do a biopsy of her left breast too! I am terrified that she now has bc as well.  That would make three sisters with bc.  My Mom is still alive (73) and was never diagnosed with it.  I was the first one who had the diagnosis. What are others thoughts on the chances of this being negative for bc despite our strong family history...some days I wish I had a crystal ball! Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 08:44PM - edited Oct 4, 2011 08:46PM by Curlylocks HI etheriz, I had 23 lymph nodes removed, full auxillary node dissection as my surgeon suspected cancer in my lymph nodes due to my tumour size of 4cm.  I had one drain which has  long thin plastic tubing (about 12" long) that is inserted into the skin during surgery and kept in place by a stitch or two.  There is a plastic bulb thingy attached to the bottom which basically collects the fluid and blood that will drain into there over the course of a week or so.  The goal is to dump it out once it gets full and record how much fluid is draining and to make sure that no clots develop in the tubing.  The nurses should show you how to check for this. It has markings on it so you can see how much is in there before you dump it.  I had my drain in for 8 days, it was uncomfortable and you have to make sure that you either pin the tubing to your clothing so it doesnt get caught or buy a drain pouch. Sleeping with the affected arm down flat hurt for a few months after the surgery, I used a pillow underneath my arm while sleeping.  Most important thing is to make sure that your medical team shows you how to do the exercises to get proper movement back into your arm. If you have any questions, send me a private message or respond here. Michele

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 09:57PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Docbabs  I am sorry that you are joining our club.  Technology does fail, I was told especially if your breasts are dense. I had a mamogram at age 40 as a baseline not due to any concerns....nothing showed on that...bam...13 months later I had a 4 cm tumour that I discovered myself. Hang in there and make sure you have a medical team that you can trust and a very good oncologist as he/she will be someone that u seee for a while.   When you go to the oncologist appt tomorrow make sure you bring a note pad and write down any questions that you can think of ahead of time, also a friend for a second set of ears or a tape recorder.  We are here to support you, the beginning days shortly after diagnosis are the most difficult, waiting for additional tests, results and surgery.  PM if you have any questions, as I said in the past I have gone through this nasty disease as well as being a support system for my younger sister within the last year. Michele

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 06:40PM - edited Feb 1, 2012 06:42PM by Curlylocks Loosing my hair was the hardest part of chemo...I had long curly ringlet like curls down past my shoulders...thus my screen name.  I had my hair cut into a cute short hair style to make it easier to loose.  I had my hubby shave it down about 2 weeks after my first treatment as it was really hard having it start to fall out in the shower.  I did my first chemo the beginning of December and did not want to have my hair fall out on Christmas Eve.  I felt I had some control over this wretched disease by shaving it off on my terms.  I wore bandanas, hated the thought of wearing a wig..went through chemo during the winter months so it was easier.  I ditched my bandana in late March as I was tired of hiding from the world that I had no hair...I wanted to send a message to those that thought that this could never happen to them.  I didnt care that some people stared at me being bald...it was liberating to let the world see "the real me" for who I was "my hair did not define my inner self", cancer had already taken enough away from me!  Going into my 7th year being cancer free...my hair is long curly and really, really thick as it was before.  I have to have my hairdresser thin it out.  Hang in there ladies...although the hair loss is really hard...it is worth coming out the other side, happy and healthy and living life beyond breast cancer!   Hugs Michele

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 06:09PM - edited Jun 21, 2008 06:11PM by Curlylocks Jude, I am 44, was 41 when diagnosed with IDC almost 3 years ago.  My tumour was 4 cm, a grade III and I had 3 positive lymph nodes.  This puts me at stage IIb due to the positive nodes.   I had a lumpectomy, 6 months of chemo, radiation, on hormonals due to estrogen positive status and had my ovaries removed a month ago so that I can remain on Armidex.  I am glad that I didnt have to make the chemo decision due to my positive nodes it was made for me.... This cancer journey is certainly not an easy one, very hard emotionally but it does get a little easier to deal with over time.... I am sorry that you are having to deal with this and hope that your fiance supports you to the fullest in this journey. Your tumour is quite large like mine was and due to the IDC despite negative nodes it will most likely be recommended for you.  You are also young in the world of breast cancer.   Cancer can travel through the blood stream, chemo will be an extra insurance policy in your arsenal to beat this disease.  None of us willingly sign up for chemo but you dont want to second guess your decision a little later on if this beast should come back.  Your first chance is your best bet to living a healthy long life.  I wish you the best in your bc journey, it is tough but I am proof that you can come out the other side of breast cancer. Michele

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 12:10AM - edited May 6, 2008 12:11AM by Curlylocks Apple Your thoughts just brought up memories of those first days after diagnosis, those dark, dark days that did get better! I am 43, was diagnosed in Oct 05-- I will be 44 in 2 weeks and also had IDC, 4 cm tumour, 3 positive lymph nodes, grade III tumour--also er/pr+, her2-. I was in treatment for almost 9 months, it was tough physically and emotionally but it was TEMPORARY.  I now have a full life and things have returned to a "new normal" beyond breast cancer! You need to assign those tasks to the older children who will help the younger children.  You will be surprised how many people will step up to the plate and help out once they are aware of your illness. Life is really worth living and fighting for especially for your children and family. Put yourself first during this journey and dont be afraid to speak up and delegate what cant be done. All the best during treatment, this is doable and many women have been in your shoes and we are here to cheer you on to ensure you get through all of this crap! Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2010 08:36PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi mintchochip (love your screen name!) I am 46 as well and will celebrate 5 years of survivorship next month!  My stats are similar to yours too! The waiting part of this journey is the absolute worst, it is hard on you but even harder on your loved ones.  They are freightened and are afraid of loosing you so their defensive mechanism kicks in and thats when you get the "everything is going to be okay" comments.  I think it is a coping mechanism. My husband had a very hard time with my diagnosis, we have been together 22 years, married for 11 years, no children. I ended up buying him the book by Marc Silverman called "The Breast Cancer Husband", it is written by a guy whose wife is doing through treatment and the thoughts and ways that he would relate to his wife and how he felt he could have changed things.  It is a very worthwhile read!  My husband also went to speak to someone and get anti depressants, that is how much it affected him, it is much harder on men as they tend to interalize their thoughts and feel hopeless that they cant fix this! Communication is the most important thing that will help your marriage and your family get through this very difficult emotional journey.  If you need help with something or are having a bad day take sometime to share it with your kids or your husband...honesty up front is the best! Dont be afraid to cry or have bad days cause they are many, many of them in the beginning as your mind tends to wander to places that it really shouldnt. I found out how hard it is being on the other side of dealing with breast cancer as my youngest sister was diagnosed in July and will be undergoing surgery for a second time on Tuesday due to unclear margins for her lumpectomy. This process if every hard emotionally, physically and changes your life.  You can live life beyond breast cancer, I am proof that it does happen! Love Michele

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 03:46PM - edited Sep 16, 2008 03:47PM by Curlylocks Jules 3, I am a 3 year survivor of IDC with an aggressive grade III tumour with some DCIS components as well, was 41 at diagnosis. I am no doctor but will try to help you understand your pathology report. Grade of your cancer is 1 which is good - how aggressive the cells look under a microscope and how aggressive the tumour is.  Tumours are graded as 1, 2 or 3 with 3 being the most aggressive. Tumour has both idc and dcis.  This may sound confusing but all it means is the cancer started off as being contained within the breast (dcis)  and then at some point it has invaded outside of the breast.  Most cancers are in our bodies for 6-8 years prior to being discovered.    80% of breast cancers are invasive. Estrogen receptor positive (also known as er+) is 100% which is another good trait as you will be able to take hormonal therapy (daily pill) after treatments typically for five years to help prevent a reoccurance.  This also means that the tumour was fueled by the estrogen in your body. It also looks like the progrestrone receptor although, weakly positive is positive too. Her2 status, is also another factor that will play a part in your treatment plan.  Yours is not amplified which is also another good trait!  It means that you will not have to take the drug Herceptin. I hope I have helped and not totally confused you...it sucks that you were given this report without an explanation. Michele

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 03:43PM - edited Jan 4, 2013 03:46PM by Curlylocks Smethot, It really sucks hearing you have positive nodes...kinda knocks the wind out of your sails.  When I received my pathology report back I had 3 positive nodes and was beyond devasted.  My hubby had to comfort and say to me "hey at least it is only 3 positive nodes out of the 23 that were removed", that didnt make me feel any better:( Having positive nodes doesnt mean that you automatically have mets and that it has spread to other parts of your body.  The positive news in all of this if you want to call it positive is that chemo loves quickly dividing cells.   Your medical team will likely do a bone scan, chest/abdomen scan and a heart test to determine how well your heart is for chemo.  These tests are used as a baseline and are pretty standard with IDC in Canada (I too am Canadian and pretty well near your neighbour!).  They also use these tests to determine if the cancer has spread to other areas of the body. All this stuff is just too scary and hard to digest especially in the beginning.  I know what you mean by wanting to get "the cancer" out of your body.  When I first found out I foolishly wished there was a way I could cut it out myself.LOL It is VERY NORMAL to have the "why me" feelings, it is not fair that we have to deal with this diagnois while others go along happily on their merry ways without a care in the world.  If only they knew who lucky they were not to be facing this disease.  The fact is that more and more women will develop breast cancer with or without a family history (I had none) just because of the fact that we are women and have breasts.  One in eight are now affected.  It doesnt mean that you didnt anything wrong....  HUGS....as I remember this feeling well.  I remember going through chemo and seeing women with their gorgeous hair and secretly wanting to cut their hair off...warped, I dont know it helped me cope! This disease is beatable, keep that in your mind when things get rough in the next little while as you wait for surgery, results of pathlogy, treatment plan to be recommended and getting on the "bus to beating the crap out of this cancer"!!!! Michele

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2012 04:13PM - edited Sep 13, 2012 04:16PM by Curlylocks Hi Dale, Sorry that your wife has been diagnosed with what should be the happiest time of your lives.  Hearing the words you have "breast cancer" is the scariest thing and our minds automatically go into a dark place where it shouldnt. I am a soon to be 7 year breast cancer survivor (diagnosed at age 41) now 48 with a 4cm tumour, was aggressive grade 3 and I had three positive lymph nodes.  Treatment was hard and even thinking about 6 months into the future in those early days was not an easy task. I went through a lumpectomy, 6 months of chemo, radiation, had my ovaries removed in 2008 due to the cancer being fed by estrogen (er+, pr+) and took a drug called Armidex for 5 years to hopefully prevent a future reoccurance.  I was diagnosed stage IIb.  This whole journey is tough emotionally, physically and trying to get yourself back into a "new normal" way of living after breast cancer is really tough.  It took me a good 3-4 years to not think about breast cancer every single minute of every day.  Fast forward to 7 years later and I can hardly believe it was me that went through all that crap!  I am healthy, breast cancer free despite positive lymph nodes and living my life beyond breast cancer.  I was never tested for the brca1 or 2 gene, my youngest sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 42 in 2010, she was tested for the gene and didnt not have it.  She unfortunately did not have a good outcome and left us in April of this year.  I have a really heartwarming story to share with you.  I am a part of a group of 15 breast cancer survivors that established friendships online here starting back in 2005, we are all still in communication with each other and get together once a year to celebrate life in various places.   The ages of us range from 28 at diagnosis to middle 60's.  Our youngest member of the group was 28 at diagnosis, she had just been married for 3 weeks when she was diagnosis with stage 3 breast cancer.  She went through all of her treatment incuding a double mastecomy with reconstruction, chemo.  She is doing extremely well 7 years later, adopted a little boy a little over 2 years ago and then just had her own child naturally two weeks ago when she was told she would never get pregnant!  NEVER GIVE UP HOPE!!!!  My motto is to never give up hope, life is too precious! Hang onto the positive, although things are very scary and unknown right now.  Give your precious wife a big hug and congratulations on the upcoming birth of your new son!  This board was a life saver for me in the beginning, I dont come here much anymore but like to pop in to offer hope to the newly diagnosed....kind of a way of giving back to those that helped me in the beginning. Michele

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 01:25PM - edited Apr 3, 2014 01:28PM by Curlylocks I am an 8.5 year two time survivor of bc.  I was diagnosed at age 41 in 2005 with a 4 cm tumour, 3 positive nodes.  My first bc was IDC, er/pr+, her2-.  I had a left breast lumpectomy with clear margins, 6 months of chemo - 4 treatments each of a/c and taxol, 5.5 weeks of radiation, ovary suppression for 1.5 years with Zoladex, Armidex and then ovaries permanently removed at age 44.  I was doing well for 8+ years. Two of my sisters were diagnosed in 2010 and 2013.  It was enough to scare me into having a prophylactic masectomy with DIEP reconstruction in Dec 2013.  My pathology results from my surgery revealed a new Primary BC in my same breast as my first bc.  This time it is Triple Negative.   If you have a full auxiliary dissection (more than the sentinel node removed) you will have a drain.  I had mine for 10 days. I am sharing this story because you asked.  I do know women that had a lumpectomy and never had to have a 2nd surgery.  This is a very personal decision and one that you have to feel comfortable with! I only wish I had that masectomy the first time! Michele

These chemicals are toxic but they are that way to kill the cancer cells that may have strayed.   Be good to yourself, get lots of rest and take it baby steps...one day at a time.  Looking at the whole picture was just too depressing for me! Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 07:22PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Elsko, I am almost a 2 1/2 year survivor, diagnosed at age 41.  It is such a scary place that you are in right now just having received "the news" and trying to digest everything emotionally. The beginning of this journey is the hardest. You DO NOT have to give up your dreams of being a doctor.  This is a temporary setback.   I took almost a year off during treatment, lumpectomy with removal of 23 lymph nodes, 6 months of chemo and 5 1/2 weeks of radiation and then two months post recovery time.  I am lucky that I work for an employer that has an excellent benefit plan so financially it wasnt a huge burden.... I am also married and had a second income to support us. Alot of the ladies here have worked throughout treatment, taking a few days off after each infusion and have done pretty okay.  It is tough but sometimes you have no choice.  Breast cancer has thought me that life is truly precious and that those that are important in our life, family, friends will help you through this.  It is easiest when you look at this journey, one step at a time, one day at a time...baby steps.   Once you have surgery, meet with your medical team and have a treatment plan in place things will be a little easier as you feel like you are doing something to get rid of this nasty beast. Breast cancer is very treatable and many women are living long healthy lives after treatment.   I was totally devasted when I was diagnosed back in Oct 05, it seemed like life was turned upside with a few little words..."you have cancer".  I had no family history of breast cancer, although other cancers and had found my 4 cm lump on my own after having had a first baseline mamogram 13 months earlier that showed no maligancy.  My tumour was a grade 3 which is aggressive and fast growing with 3 positive lymph nodes.  I cried rivers of tears for months after diagnosis, crying is healthy, cleansing and NORMAL.  If you can try to seek out a counsellor that you can talk to about your feelings.  This board is also a great support line and saved my sanity when I was diagnosed. I can honestly say that life has returned to "a new normal" now, almost 1 1/2 year post treatment.  When I was first diagnosed all I could think about was...am I going to be here tomorrow.  Those thoughts are far and few between now and planning for the future is okay and exciting now!!! As far as strength my thoughts are that we have been dealt a crappy hand of cards and have no choice but to go through treatment to get healthy again.  You will be totally surprised how much strength, spirit and determination you have when you dig down deep inside.  This is not an easy road but you can do this like so many of us have and come out the other side of living beyond breast cancer.  Moving on does not happen overnight, I still struggle the odd time to come to terms with this whole disease and have the odd cry at the unfairness of being diagnosed so young. Come back here often to ask any questions you may have.   Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 07:52PM - edited Jul 14, 2008 07:52PM by Curlylocks Hi Bonnie, I am almost 3 years post diagnosis but wanted to share my thoughts on Taxol versus A/C as that is what I had.  A/C for me sucked, totally exhausted, nauseaous, constipated and slept like a bear for almost 3 months.  Taxol does not cause nausea and felt alot better on it, I did the 3 week dose so it was alot stronger in one shot and I did well.  One drawback of taxol is the bone pain which usually lasted about 3 days for me, my oncologist prescribed celebrex for the first week following every treatment and it really helped! I had a little bit of numbness in my face and hands but it was really temporary and went away quite quickly after each infusion.  I did have sore feet but they too got better, no lasting effects from taxol at all.... Congrats on finishing the nasty red devil and all the best on the rest of your treatments! Michele

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 06:26PM - edited Mar 27, 2011 06:28PM by Curlylocks Hi suebak, I was diagnosed 5 1/2 years ago and my poor husband who always treats me like a queen and is always there no matter what was "terrified" and didnt know how to express his feelings about the possibility of loosing me.  He was scared but didnt want to admit it to me.  This is really hard on our significant others (not that it is any better on us).  Men in general have a hard time expressing themselves emotionally and generally just want to "fix it all" and it will be done and over with it.  Obviously this is something that he cannot fix..... He may need time to emotionally wrap his head around this and therefore it feels like he is distancing himself.  Do yourself a favour and sit down and talk with him about how you feel and what you would like him to do.  If need be, he may need someone to talk to (a professional), some hospitals have social workers that will help with family members.  If he is not coping with your diagnosis emotionally, he is not in any position to help you.  My husband was so angry that he punched a hole in the wall!  I told him at that point that if he didnt seek out help for himself he was not going to be in any position to support me emotionally.  He went to the doctor's that week and was prescribed anti depressants to help him cope. I am not saying that your husband needs anti depressants, but my diagnosis was enough to push my husband over the edge.  I also bought him a book by Mark Silver called "The Breast Cancer Husband", it is highly recommended...my husband read it from cover to cover and so did I.  It is written from a man's point of view on how to deal with helping your spouse through this really tough journey. Hugs, I know that it is hard trying to get through this when you feel like you "are going it alone". Now 5 1/2 years later, my husband and I have a exceptionally strong marriage....communication is the key. Love Michele

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 06:29PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Justkat, As everyone as said here, this is the worst time prior to surgery, awaiting pathology and not knowing what to expect or having a plan in place to get rid of this beast.   I am a 3 year survivor, diagnosed in October 05 at age 41 with a 4 cm tumour, grade III tumour, 3 positive nodes and er.pr+, her-.  The worst part of this whole journey is the "not knowing" what is going to happen at each point in this journey.  I was afraid prior to surgery, definitely had to be dragged kicking and screaming to my first chemo and then waited for the side effects to kick---feeling like I was a science experiment.  Our minds tend to conjur up thoughts that dont pan out in real life.  I will not lie to you treatment was tough emotionally and physically but I am proof that you can come out the other side of breast cancer and go back to living a "new normal". My husband and I had been together for 16 years and married for 6 years when I was diagnosed so I knew our relationship was strong.  I know now that it will survive anything after dealing with the emotional aftermath of a bc diagnosis.  Many days I felt sorry for myself but more importantly felt for my husband who didnt seem to have an outlet to let out his feelings and fears.  I bought a really good book for him called "The Breast Cancer Husband" which is written by Marc Silverman.  Marc's wife is a breast cancer survivor and the book is written from a "guy's" presceptive on how women are impacted by this and what to do and not to do to be a caregiver.  If your local hospital has a social worker it may be helpful to have your husband and children talk to them if needed as well as yourself as this is a "tough disease" to emotionally handle.  On the days when I have the odd emotional breakdown now (yes still at 3 years out), my husband hugs me and says we are in this journey together and that is the best way to sum it up -- you and your husband are in this battle together---good and bad days... A big hug out to you as I remember the early days of diagnosis like it was yesterday, they were soo soo hard but it does get better --PROMISE! Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 09:40PM - edited Oct 15, 2012 09:42PM by Curlylocks Karen, Here are some questions I thought of off the top of my head: The first thing that pops out at me is having a lumpectomy with radiation versus mastectomy. Has your surgeon discussed the reasons for doing one against the other? For me this is such a personal decision that only you should make based on the results of the tests after talking to the surgeon. You have the right to a 2nd opinion, I know you just want it gone but there is time to seek another opinion and take the time to make an informed decision not one out of fear. If you are doing a mastectomy will they do immediate reconstruction, does your surgeon have a recommendation for a plastic surgeon? If chemo is recommended which it probably will be with IDC, what protocol, how often and when? Will it be dose dense (every 2 weeks) or every 3? Will you be getting injections to boost blood cell count while doing chemo? - Neupegeon(sp), can't remember other one. If so do you have a benefits plan to cover it....it is extremely expensive....$2,000 plus. OHIP does not cover the injections!. If insurance will not pay may be able to get it covered under a Special Compassionate Assistance Program (hospital should be able to give you application). Is it possible for them to do a sentinel node biopsy versus a full auxiliary node dissection?Sorry cant remember whether or not you addressed this in your first post. Sential node will cut down on risk of lymphedema (unfortunately I was just diagnosed with it a few months ago..not something you want!) Once you have your er/pr status (this won't happen until after surgery and you get your pathology report...you will need your er/pr status to determine if you can take tamoxifen and/or one of the AI's if you are put into menopause either chemically with injections or permanently through ovary removal. I hope I haven't overwhelmed you...let us know how things go and I hope things turn out okay with scans! Michele

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 11:01PM - edited Oct 29, 2008 11:04PM by Curlylocks There is no significance to the 5 year mark.  The number is used for statistics only, this includes women that may have passed away from other causes than bc and also includes women that may have been older when diagnosed and died of natural causes.  It also does not take into account the new AI's (hormonals) available to estrogen positive bc and Herceptin for HER2+ bc women. Remaining cancer free for 5 years is wonderful but does not determine your chances of reoccurance or dying from bc. Breast cancer is a crap shoot and as someone said early on in my journey which started 3 years ago for me, you are either 100% alive or 100% dead.  I prefer to say that I am 100% alive because I am!! Estrogen positive women have a lifetime risk, whereas women that are triple negative have a higher survival rate once they hit the 5 year mark although their cancers tend to be more aggressive.  I have gone through treatment and remain cancer free 3 years out.   No one can predict what is going to happen to a person as far as survival as everyone responds differently to treatment, most do well and some unfortunately do not.  Some ladies that have a poor prognosis outlast others that a good prognosis. As you can see the last part of your question is a really hard one to answer as no one knows.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 05:24PM - edited Dec 2, 2007 05:41PM by Curlylocks Hi Ladies....  I am 43 and a 2 year survivor of idc, 4 cm tumour with 3 positive lymph nodes.  This journey is so tough emotionally and physically.  Digesting the news is handled so differently by everyone.  Our families suffer just as much as we do if not worse as they "want to take it all away" and make things better.  I found myself telling my parents and sisters/brother not to treat me any differently that I wasnt going to break and that we would get through this together! Hearing the words "you have cancer" has changed my life forever, I am not the same person I was 2 years ago.  I am no longer have a carefree attitude about my health or life.  I cherish my husband, family, friends even more than I ever have, they were my "rocks" in getting through a very difficult road of treatment, lumpectomy, 6 months of chemo, radiation and then hormonal treatments.  The first days, weeks and months following my diagnosis I cried alot, wondered why this happened to me so young with no family history of bc, was angry, constantly thought about cancer and that I was going to die.I would not dare think long term with respect to the future.  Crying is good for you and also very normal and healthy through this process.  I ended up having to go on a antidrepressant 1 month prior to the end of chemo as my system went into overloaded and I was not sleeping or processing any of this in a healthy way. I am still on an antidepressant but I find it keeps me on an even keel. I tried to keep busy and had the cleanest house in town while I was awaiting all my test results.  Reading a good book also helped. Deb - a big hug to you my friend, once you have a treatment plan in place you will feel a little more in control of your life.  It does get easier with each day, think "baby steps", one day at a time.  If you are having problems sleeping "ativan" does take the edge off and will allow you to sleep.  Dont worry about having to take meds right now to get through this hardest part, sleep is really important to your overall wellbeing. Dont look at the overall picture especially when you start to think about treatment.  It takes the better part of a year of your life but the tradeoff is awesome, being brought back to a healthy person once again!  I'm crossing my fingers that your sister's results are beign. I still find it hard to believe sometimes that I am a breast cancer survivor.  It is so hard to accept and being numb right now is your body's way of slowly digesting all this..... Life now is good and relatively "normal", I dont think about cancer constantly and enjoy life's fun moments...   Barb - I hope that you get good news on your test results this week. Have a good night's sleep ladies and stay warm! Michele

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 02:22AM - edited Feb 18, 2014 02:24AM by Curlylocks DCIS means Ductual Carcinoma Institu (basically cancer contained within the ducts).  Calcifications are white specks that appear on a mamogram or ultrasound.  Here is a link from Mayo: http://www.mayoclinic.org/symptoms/breast-calcifications/basics/definition/sym-20050834 Normally the pathology from the biopsy will identify any invasive portions.  The lumpectomy will remove the section of tissue in question including margins - the final pathology from that surgery will find any invasive portions if there are even any there. Try not to stress, I know easier said than done...it will just make you more anxious.  It will not change the final outcome. Michele

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 11:01PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Suzela, I am sorry that your mom is having to go through chemo.  You seem like an amazing daughter taking care of all the research on her treatments, etc. I am a five year breast cancer survivor, diagnosed at age 41 with a large 4 cm tumour with 3 positive lymph nodes, grade III tumour.  I had 8 treatments of chemo, once every 3 weeks. 4 a/c and 4 taxol. A/C is commonly used for treatment of agressive grade III cancers and node positive cancers.  It does have a small percentage of problems with heart toxicity.  I am 4 years out of chemo and have had no long term side effects from a/c or taxol.  It is difficult emotionally going through this journey.  It is comforting to have a family member or friend with you during treatments. to keep you company.  My younger sister was diagnosed with breast cancer in July of this year at age 43 and she had a larger tumour than myself but no positive lymph nodes amazingly! She unfortunately had to have a masectomy of her left breast due to unclear margins after surgery.  Her chemo drugs are 3 FEC - which is the "E" drug that you were speaking of and 3 taxtotere (which is the sister drug to taxol).  So in 5 years the same oncology clinic that I had gone to is using FEC more often as it is said to have a lesser effect on the heart.  Who knows.... I wish your mom all the best during her treatment, there is HOPE and never forget that! I am proof of that!!! Michele

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 01:49AM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Pattij, Sorry that you are facing a new bc.  I had the same thing happen to me after 8 years. My new bc is triple negative, 1 cm but due to the aggressiveness of TN I started 4 rounds of chemo started last Tuesday. Pathology will test whether or not there has been a spread to the lymph nodes.  If it is true DCIS, it should be contained within the ducts.  But until you get the pathology back there is no way of knowing 100%. It can only invade the lymph nodes if there is a mixture of IDC with the DCIS. HER2 Positive bc used to be a scary diagnosis until the introduction of Herceptin woman having been living many, many years...never give up HOPE!   Regardless of whether this is a new diagnosis or a reoccurance, treatment will be the same.  Your K167 is pretty high, which means that the cancer cells when looked at under a microscope are dividing very quickly...talk to your doctors about treatment including chemo and radiation.  Herceptin would be a definite. Try not to think the worst...I know it is hard.  If the pathology report reveals DCIS, I am not sure if it would warrant a PT Scan.  They are normally done when you have an invasive component. Hang in there...as you know having been through this crap before...the waiting truly sucks! Michele

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 09:52PM - edited Jul 1, 2009 10:01PM by Curlylocks Hi Lori,  Sorry you have had to join us.  I was diagnosed at age 41, also stage IIb with er/pr+, her- and a 4 cm tumour in October 05.  So I am an oldie here. My treatment was 4 a/c and 4 taxol.  I had 3 out of 23 positive nodes thus the extra 4 treatments of chemo.  I also had a lumpectomy with radiation, had my ovaries removed last May and am on Armidex (hormonal) drug to help prevent reoccurance for 3 years now.  Most women do loose their hair during chemo, for me it was the most traumatic part of chemo.  But it is only TEMPORARY for a good part of about 9 months and it grows back in alot of cases curly and thick, thick.  I had long curly ringlets past my shoulders before I lost my hair, got it cut short in preparation for loosing it.  I cried my eyes out when it started to fall out but then my husband shaved it off for me so it wouldnt all just come out on Christmas Day in the shower.  I did loose my eyelashes and eyebrows.  I got really good at drawing fake eyebrows and well the eyelashes just let it be.  My eyebrows and lashes came back fairly quickly about 3 weeks after the end of chemo finished.  I didnt have any problems with my nails, except my little one turned black but never fell off.  Everyone is different in how they handle this disease, the emotional impact is the hardest...it is similar to going through the grieving process.  You are grieving the loss of your old carefree life prior to bc, denial and anger are the first steps of it.  At a much later date the acceptance will come...be kind to yourself...baby steps will get your through this...one day at a time. You will soon learn how to navigate this board, it is fairly easy.  Click on the topic that you want to see and there are different subjects within those main threads.  You have figured out how to post a question and then you can also receive private emails.  If you have a private message it will show up highlighted as New under the Private Messages Tag at the top of the page.  Just click on that and you will be able to read the message and respond back to someone if you want to. All the best in your journey, it is a tough one physically and emotionally but life does return to a new normal afterwards.  I am proof that you can come out the other side of this nasty disease!  Michele

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 10:01AM Curlylocks wrote: Hi mom to 3 I was diagnosed in October 05 with IDC at age 41, 4 cm tumour and 3 positive lymph nodes.  I had a lumpectomy of my left breast and a full auxillary dissection (removal of 23 lymph nodes).  The lumpectomy part of the surgery was quite easy.  The worst part was the drains and the pain from the incision where the lymph nodes where removed. My surgeon knew I had positive nodes due to the size of my tumour on the mamogram thus I decided to have the lumpectomy and node dissection all in one surgery.  I unfortunately had to have chemo due to the cancer being a grade III and 6 weeks of radiation.   I just passed my 4 years of survivorship in October and will be 46 in May of 2010 and also remain NED (no evidence of disease). This cancer journey is really scary at first, get a 2nd opinion if you are not sure of the lumpectomy decision and weigh the pros and cons.  Do not make the decision in haste, most cancers have been in our bodies for at least 6-8 years prior to discovery, so taking your time to make the right decision with all the facts is important. All the best in your journey and if you have any questions, please do not hesitate to pm me!  Michele

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 07:52AM - edited Mar 8, 2008 07:54AM by Curlylocks I also had IDC back in October 05, that sounds so nice to say --- 2 1/2 year survivor.  I had a large 4 cm tumour with 3 positive lymph nodes.  I am here today, healthy and cancer free! My understanding of an snb is that they use die to trace to the main sentinal node that is the first node that feeds into the breast.  This is normally tested first to determine if there is cancer in the lymph nodes as this would be the first node it would hit.  In doing this procedure it looks like they may have taken a few extra in the process, in your case this is good as they were able to determine that there are 3 positive nodes.  They may go back and do a full auxillary node dissection as part of your masectomy to make sure there are no more positive nodes.  This helps to stage your cancer as well as setup a treatment plan for you. I had a full auxillary node dissection, skipped the snb as my doctor knew that I would have positive nodes due to the size of my tumour. They took a section of tissue out in the auxila area under my arm and that contained 23 lymph nodes so 5 is small in comparison.  It is also my understanding that radiation is not normally a part of treatment with a masectomy.  Chemo may be recommended in your case as you have positive nodes.  Hormonal theraphy also if your tumour is er/pr+ which means that the cancer was fueled by the estrogen in your body.  Hormonal theraphy is a drug to help prevent reoccurance.  The er/pr status is normally available with your pathology report after surgery, mine took about a week.  This helps determine what your course of treatment will be. Hang in there, it is scary and we always have our minds imaging the worst.  Dont panic if they ask you to have further scans done after this.  It is usually standard for IDC and helps stage your cancer and determine treatment too.  I had a chest xray, bone scan, liver/abdomen scan and thankfully everything was clear.  They use these scans as well for a baseline if they need to later on. Big hugs and hope that your surgery goes well. Michele

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 06:27PM Curlylocks wrote: Hi Suzie, I was diagnosed with IDC at age 41, grade 3, 4 cm tumour in October 05.  I had the full auxillary node dissection (removal of 23 lymph nodes) with my lumpectomy as my surgeon knew by the size of my tumour there would most likely be positive nodes.  Having positive nodes is not a death sentence and many women are living healthy lives after treatment---I will be a 3 year survivor in October! Your medical team will be aggressive with treatment including chemo due to the positive nodes but once you get through this life will get back to a "new normal".  Today I am happy, healthy and living cancer free and you WILL do this too! I had 6 months of chemo (8 treatments) once every 3 weeks, the worst part was fatigue and #1 hair loss.  But now my hair is wild, thicker and curly, curly like it never was....and I am once again complaining about it.  I said I would never complain about my hair when I was bald for almost 9 months, how soon we forget.LOL. Hang in there sister, we are here to answer any questions that you may have! Your bc sister Michele
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Removal Suzie67 myheidiscrapbooking

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2013 06:44PM - edited Feb 13, 2013 06:44PM by Curlylocks Indenial, I just wanted to stop by and let you know what the other ladies have said you are in the worst part of this journey...the beginning...I liken it to the "hurry up wait phase".  There will be surgery, waiting for pathlogy, finding out what treatment plan will be recommended, going for a 2nd opinion if needed.  Once you start beating down this beast, it seems a little like you have a some control over what is taking place.  The unknown is also the worst because your mind tends to go to places it should not.  Best pieces of advice hang out with these wonderful ladies her on BCO.org and get all the support you need.  They saved my life in the beginning!  Stay away from Dr. Google because in my opinion alot of information on the net is outdated and does not include the newer drugs that are available for bc. I am a 7.5 year survivor of stage IIb IDC (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma), had a 4 cm tumour and 3 positive lymph nodes.   I was diagnosed at age 41, will be 49 in May:) Treatment was tough but certainly dobable, especially chemo with the meds that they have available now, no one should have to suffer needlessly!  Emotionally was the biggest challenge for me, knowing that initially you had your whole life ahead of you, carefree not a worry in the world and then BAM this crap hits you!  Learning to not let breast cancer overtake your life is a struggle for most, but it does come eventually and we learn to live a "New Normal". For the first 2 years or so cancer occupied my thoughts every second of every day, but now I can go for days without thinking about it.  It takes alot of work but you will learn how to get there baby steps at a time.  If you need to seek out counselling to get you through some rough patches, certainly go for it, some women end up taking anti depressants for awhile.  I had never taken any medication in my life until I was diagnosed with bc, I went about treatment like a robot and then it hit me about a month before I finished chemo.  I took anti depressants for 2.5 years but have been off them for over 4 years and doing well! If friends, family offer up support during surgery, treatment, accept it.  It is time to take care of yourself and the rest will fall into place. Big hugs as I know how scary all this can be.  I made it through the other side of bc, why cant you too? Michele
Posts.Title: Please tell me I will survive this. indenial sutherndiva

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 11:52AM - edited Mar 20, 2008 11:53AM by Curlylocks Hi bcs 75, I am a 2 1/2 year breast cancer suvivor of IDC, er/pr+, her-, 4 cm tumour and 3 positive little suckers (nodes).  I am also stage IIb. I was diagnosed at age 41 in October 05, had a lumpectomy with the full auxillary node dissection, 6 months of chemo and 5 1/2 weeks of radiation, now on Armidex and Zoladex injections.  I will be getting my ovaries removed on May 26 to eliminate the Zoladex injections and so that I can stay on Armidex as I was pre-menopausal prior to bc diagnosis. Feel free to pm me with any questions that you have about chemo.  It is a tough physically and emotionally exhausting experience as is the whole bc journey.  I was not physically ill with all eight of my treatments except for the first one, once my anti nausea meds were changed I was okay. What chemo regime are you having?  I had 4 a/c and 4 taxol due to the positive lymph nodes.   Here are some chemo tips that I have learned during my treatments: - take prescribed meds on time or it will be hard to keep nausea under control - drink lots of fluids, if water starts to get old or taste bad, try adding some lemon or crystal light to it - take senekot with stool softner as the meds and the chemo drugs will constipate you, I took 2 every night before bed for about the first week of every treatment - listen to your body and sleep when you are tired, fatigue is a very big part of chemo, nothing like I have experienced before - dont be afraid to ask for help, especially if you have little ones...take others up on offers to help clean, cook meals, run to the store, etc... <> - cut your hair short prior to treatment, makes it easier when it starts to fall out, when it does start coming out ---be kind to yourself and shave it off makes it emotionally easier to handle than to have big clumps coming out in your hand.  My husband so lovely shaved my head 2 days before xmas in Dec 05---this was the TOUGHEST part of the whole chemo experience loosing my long curly locks... - buy bandanas, wigs, hats or whatever you plan on wearing prior to loosing your hair - if you are having any side effects that are uncomfortable, call your oncologist's office and let them know so that it can be taken care of Most of all you dont have to be positive all the time, scream, yell and cry when you think that you cant do anymore.  There is light at the end of this big long tunnel---I am proof that you can come out the other side of this disease and start living a "new normal" life! Big hugs... Your bc sister Michele
Posts.Title: insitu cancer 1935 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 02:32PM - edited Mar 20, 2008 02:34PM by Curlylocks Hi bcs75, Your quite welcome!  This is such a tough journey, having those dark moments are quite normal.  I still have them once in a while, it does get a easier once time passes and you are finished with treatment not to say that I dont think about cancer.  I do actually everyday but I am in a much better place than I was when I was first diagnosed and have learned slowly not to let it overtake my life.  I ended up having to go on an anti depressant for the first time in my life around 1 month prior to finishing chemo.  I just felt so defeated and wasnt in a good space.  I am proud to say though that I have been off them now for over six weeks after having taken them for almos 2 years.  Dont be afraid to ask your doctor if you feel that it will help you cope, this diagnosis could throw anyone into a tailspin....  I had my chemo once every 3 weeks, 8 treatments over the course of 6 months. Chemo started for me about three weeks after surgery.  Did your doctor give you any exercises to increase your range of motion for your arm?  The one that is most common is to stand up close to a wall and crawl your hands up the wall slowly-- this helps with the stretching and getting some of that motion back. Try to do a little more every day as it will become a little easier too....  I hope that your soreness goes away, mine took a few months not so much on the breast incision area where the tumour was removed but the incision where the lymph nodes were taken and the drain incision.  I found that sleeping with a pillow underneath my arm really helped with the soreness at night. Let me know how you are doing? Your bc sister Michele

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2008 07:20PM - edited Oct 7, 2008 07:24PM by Curlylocks Hi Swimangel I had an oopherectomy in May, stage IIb here, also highly er/pr+ - 44 years young.  It was done laproscopically and a fairly easy surgery, I am glad that I no longer have to worry about my ovaries. <>Just my luck for the first time in my life I unfortunately had high grade precancerous cells of my cervix last fall, discovered on a routine pap.  I had a cone biopsy to remove the area at the same time as my oopherectomy this past May.  If the cells come back abnormal again on my followup, the rest of my female parts are going for it too....dont need any more worries about constant followup. I asked about a total hysterectomy when I found out about the high grade cells but my gynecologist didnt want to do it because if the cells came back invasive they would have done the wrong time of hyster.  If it turn out invasive, I would have needed the surgery at a cancer hospital.  Will see what happens next month at my followup....
